awd_titl_txt: Assessing Educational Pathways for Manufacturing in Rural Communities: An Investigation of New and Existing Programs in Northwest Florida
awd_abstract_narration:
With the call for building the nation's skilled technical workforce, the demand for middle skill professionals in technical fields in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) is increasing. The alignment of educational programming and job requirements for STEM-oriented technician sectors is essential for establishing career pathways that produce high quality middle skills professionals for technology-rich fields. Building on prior research on career pathways in Information Technologies (IT) this targeted research project investigates the alignment of educational programming, employer needs, and new employee experience in Advanced Manufacturing (AM) and tests the usefulness of tools and processes developed to assess such alignment. Focusing on the opportunities and challenges in rural areas, the overarching goal of the project is to improve rural manufacturing capacity by better understanding the relationships among curriculum, employer expectations, and student readiness for jobs in AM.

The quantitative and qualitative mixed methods research design combines content analysis and text mining with surveys, and interviews/focus groups. A review of the literature frames the study by integrating the literature on advanced manufacturing education, employment qualifications for technology-rich technician fields, and readiness to engage in entrepreneurship and intrapreneurship as employee or innovator/small business owner. The research design, instrument development, and data analyses will be guided by a theoretical approach that blends theories of human, social, and cultural capital. The research team will apply text mining approaches for text preprocessing and keyword extraction to identify learning outcomes specified in syllabi; tokenize the text; extract and identify keywords; and match national, state, and professional standards and requirements for industry certificates/certifications with course syllabi and job postings. Qualitative analysis of interviews and focus groups will examine the expectations of employers and employees through an iterative process for clustering data into themes until saturation and themes have stabilized. The extent of matching among data from different sources will be calculated and examined for congruence and divergence of educational programming and job requirements. The testing of tools/instruments and processes for conducting analyses of educational programing with job requirements in advanced manufacturing will confirm the viability of an approach for analyzing career pathways in other STEM-oriented technician programs.

por.por_cntn:
Overview: 

Chipola College (Chipola) and Florida State University (FSU), with the collaboration and advice of the Florida Advanced Technological Education Center (FLATE), Pensacola State College (PSC), Gulf Coast State College (GCSC), Tallahassee Community College (TCC), Northwest Florida Manufacturing Consortium (NWFMC) conducted a 5-year Targeted Research study to document the school-to- career pathways enabled by the Advanced Manufacturing (AM) programs at collaborating colleges in rural Northwest Florida. This empirical study built on the findings and recommendations from the current FSU, Chipola, and Tallahassee Community College (TCC) successful research collaboration in which the team assessed IT school-to-career pathways in rural Northwest Florida (NSF 1304382). Guided by the overarching research question (RQ) "To what extent are curriculum content, employer needs, and student experiences aligned within an advanced manufacturing educational pathway," this study's goals were to 1) investigate the role of) advanced manufacturing program pathways in meeting the needs of employers and new professionals (working three years or less) in the region; 2) expand the research base and curriculum recommendations for entrepreneur and intrapreneur education; 3) further disseminate, replicate, and refine study approaches through regional academies, which Chipola and FSU, in collaboration with FLATE, to empower rural Panhandle colleges to perform ongoing AM program assessment in advanced technology programs at each college. The project team met their goals for intellectual merit and broader impact.

Intellectual Merit:

The intellectual merit of the proposed study is based on the ATE program's research priority to include research on and implementation with other types of participants at other locations under different conditions to test development efforts or innovations. Concerning Goal 1, the team determined that while formal curriculum imparted core concepts to students, new professionals reported internships, apprenticeships, and on-the-job training as critical to meeting employers’ expectations. Employers reported satisfaction and viewed the curriculum as a knowledge base for new professionals to build on the job. While gaining “just in time” skills contributed to employer and employee satisfaction, the skills tended to be very site-specific and limited AM technicians’ abilities to move from AM industry sub-sectors. In relation to Goal 2, researchers concluded AM technicians in rural communities often have many linkages to employers and strong commitment to remaining local; for these reasons, technicians’ desires to engage in intrapreneurial leadership activities were strong, as were opportunities to develop complementary businesses to expand AM employers’ capabilities. These findings were derived through a natural language processing comparative analysis of employer and new professional interview transcripts and syllabi content. This analytical approach represented a further development of the analyses conducted in the prior project and is reflected in 4 journal articles, 25 papers in conference proceedings, 12 conference presentations, and 1 dissertation.

Broader Impacts:

This collaborative research aligned educators’ efforts directly with employers’ and new professionals’ needs to facilitate economic development and support NSF ATE's goal of improving and supporting the dynamic education of technicians in the workplace. To meet Goal 3, we worked in a representative, highly diverse rural locale and provided faculty, employers, new professionals, and students in three Regional Academies for to provide access to research results and learning opportunities to build regional capacity for the AM workforce through employment, entrepreneurship, and intrapreneurship. Academy 1 focused on mapping syllabi to AM competencies; Academy 2 centered on employer engagement and interviewing; Academy 3 focused on results integration and action planning. The scholarly products resulting from this work, which also reflect the Regional Academies’ content, contribute to advising and assessing students before enrollment, a clearer understanding of students’ required outcomes, employer needs, employee development engagement in employer success through intrapreneurship, and delivery of aspects of technical education. The research results also informed FSU’s successful efforts to establish an advanced manufacturing research and education center in the Panhandle, thus ensuring the results are sustained through real-world application.  

 


Last Modified: 12/28/2023
Modified by: Marcia A Mardis
